I remember when I was little I always watched how it's made with my grandfather at night, usually when I stayed over for a day. We really watched them at any time but one of my most vivid memories with him was one night that I was staying over and just after we finished making some late night sandwiches (which we always did at night when I stayed over) we started watching how it's made. He always explained to me how the things that were shown in the show worked in his own words, dumbing it down for me and if they had other uses as well. He was very bright and his story is amazing, going from a little kid who didn't even know how to read, to a man who knew how to fix and make anything, and I mean anything.

He passed away a while ago, but every time I watch how it's made it reminds me of him, as silly as it may sound. It always brings back good memories.

Most of these machines haven’t changed all that much from the early 20th century. Most are generally the same as they were 80 years ago. Wow i have never seen a banbarry that clean. this must be a research test facility for tires. a banbarry is were all the compounds get mixed with carbon black because rubber is clean and white.

the tire machines looks along the lines of what you would call a G3 OR a VMI or a PLT

They dont use paint like this any more. to expensive.

different tire take different cure times depending on compound and size.

when they cook they tend to have flash. . flash is thin rubber that gets squeezed out of the mold and tire. real thin and makes tires look ugly.

tires go to grinders and inspections to smooth and balance the tires.

then they get shipped. theres alot more to tire building than shown in this video.

As an over-the-road driver I at times got to see some products being made because I picked them up and had to walk through the plant in order to get to the Shipping Office.  I've seen tires done but didn't quite know exactly what I was seeing.  Now I know.  I've also had the chance to see cars being made, certain food items, the stages of paper among other things.  I started driving in 1991 and drivers could move about plants more than they can today.  Well, there were a few incidents that caused OSHA to come in because untrained or poorly trained people screwed up.  There was one incident I recall where a rookie driver tried to use equipment in a grocery warehouse and was injured by it.  The warehouse had to shell out over one million dollars due to a lawsuit.  The driver thought they could do what they saw more experienced ones doing without any training and ended up with a foot injury.  Now if you unload your trailer at a grocery warehouse you have to use a manual pallet jack instead of the electric one or a forklift.
Awesome!

So to recap: the rubber is first coated with rubber, then magic string and wires are also coated with rubber, then it's all bonded together with more rubber-coated-rubber and stripes are painted on it to indicate what types of rubber were used, then it's placed in a mold and expanded and heated until the rubber becomes a different type of rubber.
